snippet: The first few months of 2009 will be rich with new and returning shows.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, television's prime-time lineups were decimated during the early months of the year by the writers' strike. In 2009, partly as a result of that strike and partly because of the remaking of the traditional television schedule by cable, the DVR and the Internet, the next few months will be rich with new and returning shows -- in fact, there will probably be more interesting television to watch than there was during the official beginning of the season last fall. Here is a look at some of the notable premieres, with their scheduled dates. SCRUBS (ABC, Tuesday) A new network and cast member (Courteney Cox) for what is expected to be the hospital comedy's final season.

headline.main: Better Than the Fall? A Host Of TV Series, New and Not

snippet: 8 P.M. (13, 49) CYRANO DE BERGERACKevin Kline, left,  plays ''Edmond Rostand's proboscisly challenged 17th-century warrior,'' as the ''Great Performances'' press material describes him, in this Broadway production taped on Jan. 3 and 4, 2008....
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) CYRANO DE BERGERACKevin Kline, left, plays ''Edmond Rostand's proboscisly challenged 17th-century warrior,'' as the ''Great Performances'' press material describes him, in this Broadway production taped on Jan. 3 and 4, 2008. Jennifer Garner is Roxane, the apple of Cyrano's eye -- if only his nose weren't in the way -- and Daniel Sunjata is the tongue-tied Christian de Neuvillette, the man she thinks she loves. Writing in The New York Times, Ben Brantley said the production ''goes down so easily, you're drunk and misty-eyed before you know it.'' 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The Top 10 health trends of 2009. Also, a chair that promises a good abdominal workout at a desk; an electronic cigarette; and designer babies.

snippet: ''The People's Choice Awards'' lifted CBS to a narrow prime-time victory on Wednesday, averaging 9.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. That was an improvement over last year, when just 6 million tuned in to a taped broadcast that was...
lead_paragraph: ''The People's Choice Awards'' lifted CBS to a narrow prime-time victory on Wednesday, averaging 9.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. That was an improvement over last year, when just 6 million tuned in to a taped broadcast that was scaled down because of the writers' strike, but well short of the 11.3 million who watched in 2007. The two-hour awards show led at 9 p.m. but trailed at 10 behind ABC's Barbara Walters special ''Patrick Swayze: The Truth'' (12.6 million) and NBC's ''Law & Order'' (10.1 million). ABC ranked second for the night, garnering 8 million viewers for ''20/20.'' CBS led the 8 o'clock hour with reruns of ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (8.2 million) and ''Gary Unmarried'' (7.4 million). NBC finished third over all, and Fox was fourth.

byline.original: By BENJAMIN TOFF; Compiled by DAVE ITZKOFF

snippet: Patrick Swayze has been hospitalized with pneumonia, days before the premiere of his A&E series, "The Beast."
lead_paragraph: Patrick Swayze, who is suffering from pancreatic cancer, has been hospitalized with pneumonia, executives from the A&E Network accounted today. Swayze had been scheduled to head a panel discussion today promoting his new drama series, "The Beast," in which he plays an FBI agent who teams with a rookie partner to infiltrate a weapons smuggling ring, at the Television Critics Association meeting in Universal City, Calif. Bob DeBitetto, the president and general manager of the A&E Network, announced there this morning that Mr. Swayze had checked himself into a hospital for observation after recently contracting pneumonia. Swayze was diagnosed with advanced stage four pancreatic cancer last January, and has been undergoing chemotherapy. The 13-episode series, which is scheduled to premiere on A&E on Jan. 15, has been completely filmed, executives said.
abstract: Patrick Swayze has been hospitalized with pneumonia, days before the premiere of his A&E series, "The Beast."

snippet: Patrick Swayze’s performance in “The Beast,” a new crime drama beginning on Thursday on A&E, is impressive for its resistance to cliché and remarkable for the mere fact of its execution.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Swayze's performance as an ungoverned F.B.I. man in ''The Beast,'' a new crime drama beginning on Thursday on A&E, is impressive for its resistance to cliché and remarkable for the mere fact of its execution. Not long after the pilot was shot last year, Mr. Swayze was given a diagnosis of Stage 4 pancreatic cancer, but chose to stay with the project, receiving treatments throughout production. During the filming of 12 subsequent episodes, as producers explained at the Television Critics Association press tour this week, the actor missed only a single day of work.

snippet: 10 P.M. (Discovery) TREASURE QUEST This new series ventures into international waters as Odyssey Marine Exploration -- a crew of researchers, deep-ocean marine archaeologists, conservators and R.O.V. (remotely operated vehicle) pilots -- plunges to...
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Discovery) TREASURE QUEST This new series ventures into international waters as Odyssey Marine Exploration -- a crew of researchers, deep-ocean marine archaeologists, conservators and R.O.V. (remotely operated vehicle) pilots -- plunges to the ocean floor in search of precious artifacts, like the one at left, from shipwrecks. Gregg Stemm, the Odyssey chairman, and Tom Dettweiler, the leader of the team that discovered the Titanic, are the men in charge. The season begins with a journey to a secret location in the English Channel. SCHEDULE NOTE Most channels broadcasting the presidential address at 8 p.m. were planning to join repeat episodes in progress following the speech; CBS was planning to show its full schedule. But specific schedules and times had not been released by press time.

snippet: The actor Patrick Swayze, who was hospitalized a week ago with pneumonia, was released on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The actor Patrick Swayze, who was hospitalized a week ago with pneumonia, was released on Friday and was resting at his Los Angeles area home, People magazine reported. Mr. Swayze, 56, the star of the new A&E series "The Beast," was told a year ago that he had Stage 4 pancreatic cancer and worked on the first season of "The Beast" while undergoing chemotherapy. Mr. Swayze missed only one day of work while filming the 13-episode season of "The Beast."
abstract: The actor Patrick Swayze, who was hospitalized a week ago with pneumonia, was released on Friday.

lead_paragraph: Patrick Swayze, who was hospitalized a week ago with pneumonia, was released on Friday and was resting at his Los Angeles-area home, People magazine reported. Mr. Swayze, 56, the star of the new A&E series ''The Beast,'' learned a year ago that he had Stage 4 pancreatic cancer and he worked on the first season of ''The Beast'' while undergoing chemotherapy. Mr. Swayze missed only one day of work while filming the 13-episode season of ''The Beast.''

snippet: 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES  The series moves into a new time slot with back-to-back episodes. In the first, Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) join a circus as a knife-throwing act to uncover the killer of conjoined twins. The suspects...
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES The series moves into a new time slot with back-to-back episodes. In the first, Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) join a circus as a knife-throwing act to uncover the killer of conjoined twins. The suspects include the ringmaster (Andy Richter, above), a strong man and some rather devious clowns. At 9, Booth becomes a suspect in the murder of a hockey player with whom he had come to fisticuffs in the past, and Brennan gets a new F.B.I. partner (Marisa Coughlan) to help with the case. The former N.H.L. star Luc Robitaille appears as himself. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Emily Post's great-great-granddaughter discusses wedding etiquette. Other segments look at Academy Award nominees and Air Force One.

snippet: Illustrating Karl Marx's lesser-known maxim that history repeats itself first as a chick flick and second as a musical, the 1990 romance "Ghost" will become the latest cinematic weepie to be translated to the stage.
lead_paragraph: Illustrating Karl Marx's lesser-known maxim that history repeats itself first as a chick flick and second as a stage musical, the 1990 romance "Ghost" will become the latest cinematic weepie to be translated to the stage. The creative team of "Ghost: The Musical" announced that they would be adapting the supernatural film, in which Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore famously got frisky around a pottery wheel, for a production to open in London's West End in 2010. Bruce Joel Rubin, who won an Academy Award for the original screenplay, will write the book and lyrics, and Dave Stewart and Glen Ballard will write music and lyrics; Matthew Warchus (Broadway's coming "God of Carnage") will direct. No casting or theater was announced. A musical version of the romantic comedy "Sleepless in Seattle," planned for Broadway in 2010, was announced earlier this week.BONUS: Janet Maslin's Times review of "Ghost" ("Current Hollywood thinking extends into the next world, but not very far") can be found here.
abstract: Illustrating Karl Marx's lesser-known maxim that history repeats itself first as a chick flick and second as a musical, the 1990 romance "Ghost" will become the latest cinematic weepie to be translated to the stage.

snippet: An Oscar-winning story gets new life, but will anything be lost in translation?
lead_paragraph: HERE'S the pitch: Two guys, old college buddies. One's a has-been TV actor, the other a never-been writer. The actor is about to get married, and the writer loves wine, so before the wedding they drive up the coast of California for a weeklong vineyard-visiting road trip.

snippet: 8:30 P.M. (HBO) TROUBLE THE WATER (2008) Kimberly Rivers Roberts (above, with her husband, Scott Roberts), a resident of the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans, documented Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath with her video camera; the filmmakers Tia...
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (HBO) TROUBLE THE WATER (2008) Kimberly Rivers Roberts (above, with her husband, Scott Roberts), a resident of the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans, documented Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath with her video camera; the filmmakers Tia Lessin and Carl Deal met Ms. Roberts at a Red Cross shelter and made her the centerpiece of this movie, which was nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary feature. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said the filmmakers ''have created an ingeniously fluid narrative structure that, when combined with Ms. Roberts's visuals, news material and their own original 16-millimeter film footage, ebbs and flows like great drama.'' 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYBeyoncé Knowles uses two names to promote her new film, ''Obsessed,'' before moving to ''The View,'' at 11, on ABC, where Meghan McCain is a guest host. Amy Poehler talks about her latest endeavor, ''Parks and Recreation,'' on ''Today'' and then moves to ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9, on ABC.

snippet: Francis Ford Coppola makes his own kind of film with “Tetro,” his second movie in two years.
lead_paragraph: FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA turned 70 a couple of months ago, but he shows no sign of slowing down. After a frustrating decade with nary a directing credit to his name, now comes ''Tetro,'' which is his second movie in two years and is based on the first original screenplay he has written, directed and produced since ''The Conversation'' in 1974. ''I view this as the second film of my second career,'' Mr. Coppola said late last month, shortly after returning from Cannes, where ''Tetro'' was described by European critics as somewhat uneven but intriguing, emotional and elegiac. ''From now on I'm always going to be writing the scripts, and every film will be personal. I'm going to be the kind of filmmaker I wanted to be when I was beginning.''

snippet: The show drew notice when its production was announced last June, about six months after Patrick Swayze was given a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.
lead_paragraph: The A&E drama "The Beast," which starred Patrick Swayze as an undercover F.B.I. agent, will not be renewed for a second season, The Associated Press reported. The show, whose 13-episode run began in January, drew notice when its production was announced last June, about six months after Mr. Swayze was given a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. Mr. Swayze continued to work on the series under the supervision of doctors hired by A&E and his own physicians. Though recent reports had indicated "The Beast" was likely canceled, A&E did not confirm the show's fate until Monday.
abstract: The show drew notice when its production was announced last June, about six months after Patrick Swayze was given a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.

snippet: Matthew Warchus is following up the rare feat of being nominated twice for the 2009 Tony Award for best director by developing two major musicals at the same time.
lead_paragraph: HOW does Matthew Warchus follow up the rare feat of being nominated twice for the 2009 Tony Award for best director, for Yasmina Reza's ''God of Carnage'' and Alan Ayckbourn's ''Norman Conquests''? By developing two major musicals at the same time, to open at roughly the same time next year.

headline.main: After the Tony, Two Musical Encores

lead_paragraph: Patrick Swayze, the balletically athletic actor who rose to stardom in the films "Dirty Dancing" and "Ghost" and whose 20-month battle with advanced pancreatic cancer drew wide attention, died Monday. He was 57.

snippet: Mr. Swayze was a balletically athletic actor who rose to stardom in the films “Dirty Dancing” and “Ghost.”
lead_paragraph: Patrick Swayze, the balletically athletic actor who rose to stardom in the films ''Dirty Dancing'' and ''Ghost'' and whose 20-month battle with advanced pancreatic cancer drew wide attention, died Monday. He was 57. His publicist, Annett Wolf, told The Associated Press in Los Angeles that Mr. Swayze had died with family members at his side.

headline.main: Patrick Swayze Dies at 57; Actor With Physical Grace

abstract: Actor Patrick Swayze, most famous for roles in Ghost and Dirty Dancing, dies at age 57 of pancreatic cancer; Swayze was classically trained ballet and Broadway dancer; first notable film was The Outsiders; photos (M)

snippet: Bolstered by ''The Jay Leno Show,'' NBC won the night by a slight margin, garnering an average of 9.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 for the premiere of ''The Biggest Loser,'' according to Nielsen's estimates, the series's highest-rated fall debut in...
lead_paragraph: Bolstered by ''The Jay Leno Show,'' NBC won the night by a slight margin, garnering an average of 9.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 for the premiere of ''The Biggest Loser,'' according to Nielsen's estimates, the series's highest-rated fall debut in five years. CBS was runner-up, with a lineup that included a rerun of ''NCIS'' (12 million) and the two-hour season finale of ''Big Brother'' (7.9 million). ABC ranked third with the finale of ''Shaq Vs.'' (4.3 million) and a repeat of a Barbara Walters interview special with Patrick Swayze (6.1 million). Fox finished in fourth with the finale of ''More to Love'' (4.3 million).
abstract: NBC's The Biggest Loser, bolstered by Jay Leno Show, garners top overnight ratings (S)

snippet: ONE after the other, they were dying: Michael Jackson, Farrah Fawcett and Ed McMahon, all in the same week earlier this summer. Next were Walter Cronkite, John Hughes and, in late August, at a pitch point of public grief, Senator Edward M. Kennedy....
lead_paragraph: ONE after the other, they were dying: Michael Jackson, Farrah Fawcett and Ed McMahon, all in the same week earlier this summer. Next were Walter Cronkite, John Hughes and, in late August, at a pitch point of public grief, Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Then on Monday, Patrick Swayze died after a widely publicized struggle with pancreatic cancer, only to be followed by Mary Travers of Peter, Paul and Mary Wednesday night. It has been, by all appearances, the endless funereal season, with a news media swarm on the departed and a parade of nostalgic tributes, as bloggers and Twitterers went on ''celebrity death watch.'' Even before Senator Kennedy succumbed to brain cancer Aug. 25, columnists wrote pleading laments like one in The Washington Post that said, ''God, please stop taking away our celebrities.''

headline.main: A Troubling Timeline for a Certain Age Group

abstract: Baby boomers cope with seemingly large number of celebrity deaths over past summer; many who died played role in defining boomer generation; photos (M)

snippet: 8 P.M. (HBO) MADAGASCAR: ESCAPE 2 AFRICA (2008) Ben Stiller, Chris Rock, David Schwimmer and Jada Pinkett Smith reprise their roles as the voices of a group of New York zoo animals -- a caged lion, a yakety zebra, a neurotic giraffe and a voluptuous...
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) MADAGASCAR: ESCAPE 2 AFRICA (2008) Ben Stiller, Chris Rock, David Schwimmer and Jada Pinkett Smith reprise their roles as the voices of a group of New York zoo animals -- a caged lion, a yakety zebra, a neurotic giraffe and a voluptuous hippo -- that crash-land their rickety plane on the African continent in this animated sequel. Sacha Baron Cohen does a turn as a deranged lemur, Bernie Mac plays a lion's lion, and Alec Baldwin chimes in as -- who else? -- the resident bad guy. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said the movie was ''good enough in patches to make its distracting star turns, storybook clichés and stereotypes harder to take than they would be in a less enjoyable movie.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY The Putlitzer Prize-winning author Marilynne Robinson (''Gilead'') talks about the environment, changing values and how she sees holiness in everything. Also, a look at the online Second Life Church.

snippet: GIVEN THE LIMITATIONS OF HIS ROLE, that of a poor but handsome sex-object abused by the rich women at Kellerman's Mountain House, Mr. Swayze is also good. He's even convincing when he must admit, in one of the  film's lesser moments, that ''the...
lead_paragraph: GIVEN THE LIMITATIONS OF HIS ROLE, that of a poor but handsome sex-object abused by the rich women at Kellerman's Mountain House, Mr. Swayze is also good. He's even convincing when he must admit, in one of the film's lesser moments, that ''the reason people treat me like nothing is because I am nothing.'' He's at his best--as is the movie--when he's dancing. --Review of ''Dirty Dancing'' by Vincent Canby in The New York Times. Patrick Swayze died last week at the age of 57.
abstract: Excerpt from Aug 21, 1987, review of movie Dirty Dancing, starring Patrick Swayze, who died on Sept 14

snippet: 9 P.M. (CNBC) THE NEW AGE OF WAL-MART Last year Wal-Mart managed the unthinkable and sold more than $400 billion worth of goods, thriving as the economy tanked. Following ''The Age of Wal-Mart,'' his 2004 Peabody Award-winning documentary, David...
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CNBC) THE NEW AGE OF WAL-MART Last year Wal-Mart managed the unthinkable and sold more than $400 billion worth of goods, thriving as the economy tanked. Following ''The Age of Wal-Mart,'' his 2004 Peabody Award-winning documentary, David Faber (above left, with Michael T. Duke, Wal-Mart's chief executive) explores efforts being made by this retailer, the world's largest, to reinvent itself. He also tours stores in Beijing with C. Douglas McMillon, the new chief executive of Wal-Mart International, and follows a covert Wal-Mart team as it crisscrosses the United States to determine where to build a store. 7 P.M. (13, 49) THE NEWSHOUR WITH JIM LEHRER Paul Solman offers a preview of the G-20 meeting this week in Pittsburgh.

snippet: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, October 3rd 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to...
lead_paragraph: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, October 3rd 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

snippet: 8 P.M. (Travel) GHOST ADVENTURES LIVE! The ghostbusters --  Nick Groff, Zak Bagans and Aaron Goodwin, from left above -- journey to Weston, W.Va., where they will lock themselves into the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum for a seven-hour report on any...
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Travel) GHOST ADVENTURES LIVE! The ghostbusters -- Nick Groff, Zak Bagans and Aaron Goodwin, from left above -- journey to Weston, W.Va., where they will lock themselves into the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum for a seven-hour report on any ghostly activity to be found in this supposedly haunted landmark, built from hand-cut stone during the Civil War and closed in 1994. Among the more gruesome procedures performed at the hospital in the 1930s and '40s was the ''ice pick lobotomy,'' perfected by Dr. Walter Freeman, who, after rendering patients unconscious by way of electroconvulsive therapy, would insert an ice pick between the eyeball and eyelid and hammer it into the frontal lobe of the brain through the eye socket. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Ms. Winfrey interviews Lisa Niemi, the widow of Patrick Swayze.

snippet: Complexions Contemporary Ballet is still thrashing, spinning and kicking along its merry way.
lead_paragraph: Back when Complexions Contemporary Ballet was known as Complexions -- A Concept in Dance, it wasn't a given that the troupe would last. Now, 15 years later, the company, formed by Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, two former Alvin Ailey dancers, is still thrashing, spinning and kicking along its merry way. As part of Complexion's latest season, called ''Love, Sweat and Tears'' and seen Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, the company presented two New York premieres by its resident choreographer, Mr. Rhoden. (Subsequent evenings will feature ''15th Anniversary Medley,'' a selection of repertory works.)

headline.main: Supple Limbs in a Sea of Energy
